qas.question: What did the US begin building in 1941?
Who primarily used the bases in Bermuda?

answers.text: US Air Force transport and refuelling aircraft and by US Navy aircraft

qas.question: What was the navy patrolling for?

answers.text: enemy submarines, first German and, later, Soviet

qas.question: What was the Naval Air Station Bermuda originally?
What is the Naval Air Station used for?

answers.text: host both transient and deployed USN and USAF aircraft, as well as transitioning or deployed Royal Air Force and Canadian Forces aircraft.

qas.question: What consisted of 5.8 sq mi of land?
Where was Air Force Base Kindley located?
What was transferred to the US Navy in 1907?

context: <b5_0>Construction<b5_0/> began in 1941 of <a0_0><b6_0>two airbases<b6_0/><a0_0/> consisting of 5.8 km2 (2.2 sq mi) of land, largely reclaimed from the sea. For many years, Bermuda's bases were used by <a1_0>US Air Force transport and refuelling aircraft and by US Navy aircraft<a1_0/> patrolling the Atlantic for <a2_0>enemy submarines, first German and, later, Soviet<a2_0/>. The principal installation, <a3_0><b8_0>Kindley Air Force Base<b8_0/><a3_0/> on the <b7_0>eastern coast<b7_0/>, was transferred to the US Navy in 1970 and redesignated Naval Air Station Bermuda. As a naval air station, the base continued to <a4_0>host both transient and deployed USN and USAF aircraft, as well as transitioning or deployed Royal Air Force and Canadian Forces aircraft.
